Award.AwardTitle: Interdisciplinary Training in Neuroscience for Faculty and Undergraduates from 2- and 4-year Institutions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) project from the University of Missouri - Columbia addresses the need for professional development for biological sciences faculty in the area of computational neuroscience. Computational neuroscience is an emerging area that studies brain function in terms of the information processing properties of the structures that make up the nervous system. It is an interdisciplinary science that links the diverse fields of neuroscience, cognitive science, and psychology with electrical engineering, computer science, mathematics, and physics. While leading biology educators call for strong interdisciplinary curricula that include physical science, information technology, and mathematics, many biological and behavioral scientists lack adequate training in the quantitative sciences, limiting their understanding and use of tools from this area. Similarly, engineers and quantitative scientists lack the training in biological sciences and neuroscience necessary to understand the details of the diverse systems in biology, and facilitate improved interactions with biologists to develop relevant and advanced computational tools.

The PI team is building on the knowledge they have gained through their prior NSF-funded work in the development of a computational neuroscience course, as well as on their seven years of experience providing a professional development workshop entitled "Hardware and Software Experiments to Teach Undergraduate Neuroscience." The workshops offered through this project are enhancing the teaching expertise of faculty in neuroscience at both 2- and 4-year institutions. Faculty-student teams participate in one-week workshops that include instructional methodologies emphasizing computation via free software experiments. Bringing this expertise back to their home institutions, workshop participants are increasing the number and diversity of undergraduates studying computational neuroscience. In addition, an intensive two-week curriculum development course will be offered to four faculty-student teams. These rigorous workshops provide training in mathematics, software, teaching, and development of curricular modules in computational neuroscience and include a one-year long support program for faculty-student teams as they develop and implement software modules into their curriculum. In the course of the project, the PI team is also augmenting our knowledge of obstacles to the implementation of effective instructional practices by carrying out studies to identify barriers to student learning and to faculty professional development and implementation of effective teaching practices. Understanding these impediments will facilitate development of strategies to overcome them so that effective instructional practices can be more widely adopted in the nation's institution of higher education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
1.  Our project addressed the tremendous interest in using open-source virtual labs (no-cost software tutorials) to teach neuroscience, possibly due to the following three reasons: (i) the numbers of neuroscience majors are growing rapidly around the nation; (ii) recognition that computation does have a role in neuroscience; (iii) that such ‘free’ software tools to teach neuroscience are mature and are probably viable tools to neuroscience concepts, compared to the huge investment required to set up neuroscience labs. These open-source ‘virtual labs’ that can be hosted on faculty and student laptops for self-paced learning.

2.  We provided training to 53 faculty from 2- and 4-year institutions (spread across 27 states in US) in understanding the role of computation in teaching neuroscience, and provided hands-on experience in using open-source virtual labs (software tutorials) in explaining the complex neuroscience concepts. Faculty came from diverse departments including biology, psychology, natural sciences, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, computer science, mathematics and physics.

3.  Focus was on both understanding how computations/math (assuming only a high school calculus background) can be used effectively to teach neuroscience. All course modules are and will continue to be freely accessible to the public indefinitely via a Canvas site  http://courses.missouri.edu  (go to very bottom and click on “Canvas Guest & Visitor Login” username: cns  passwd: workshop)

4.  To date, we have published two articles that benefited from the present grant and included evaluation data from this project, and one presentation at a national workshop:
-          Latimer B, Bergin DB, Guntu V, Schulz DJ, Nair SS (2018), Integrating model-based approaches into a neuroscience curriculum – An interdisciplinary neuroscience course in engineering, IEEE Transactions on Education (in press).
-          Latimer B, Bergin DB, Schulz DJ, Nair SS (2018), Open source software tools for teaching neuroscience, Journal of Undergraduate Neuroscience Education (in press).
-          A set of two articles led by faculty from 2016 and 2017 NSF IUSE workshops are being finalized for submission to the Journal of Undergraduate Neuroscience Education, with a focus on identifying appropriate mathematics and computation topics for incorporation into undergraduate curricular at two levels: introductory and advanced. A unique aspect is that this effort is being driven by 2- and 4-year college faculty, and so has the potential to be of interest to undergraduate neuroscience faculty in the nation and also globally.
-          We presented a 4-hour workshop at the Faculty for Undergraduate Neuroscience meetings annual meeting in Chicago, IL in July 2017.
 
5.  We have formed a community of neuroscience faculty from 2- and 4-year institutions with interest in understanding more about the role of mathematics and computation in neuroscience, and in proactively developing modules (as either modifications of those provided to them or as new ones with possible input from us) for use in their courses. This community continues to ‘meet’ via regular phone conferences including interested faculty, and has led to on-going work on two journal articles cited above.

6.  Finally, the schedule for the workshop is listed below, a version of which has been offered annually continuously at Missouri for the past decade (and will continue to be).

Table 1. Schedule of the workshop, a shortened version of which will continue to be offered. 

Prior to arrival on Univ of Missouri campus - A primer we developed ‘Basics of Neurobiology’ is sent to participants a month prior to Workshop. Participants are also provided access to the Canvas site with all materials (see above) 

Morning (8 am - 12 pm)

Afternoon (1 pm - 5 pm)

Monday. Basic Math: derivatives and integration

Biology: Resting potential and GHK-equation

Voltage-gated channels and AP

Hardware Expt. 1 – Recordings of earthworm sensory and muscle potentials; Math in Bio

Software Expts. 1 & 2 – Rest and AP

Tuesday. Bursting; Synaptic transmission

Software Expt. 3 – Bursting

Wednesday. Soft. Expt. 4: Spiking using synapses

Soft. Expt. 5: Central pattern generator

Thursday. Soft. Expt. 6: Modeling earthworm escape reflex using synapses and neurons;

Soft. Expt. 7: Modeling networks - short term memory, half-center oscillator, etc.

Friday. Ideas for software experiments

Ends at 12:00 noon on Friday
